response.answer_text: Some ideas about Freelancing for “beginner” Freedom never comes free & thus here are few factors worth considering before choosing a full-time freelancing career.Portfolio If you need to build these up you may have to get some unpaid or low paid experience under your belt before you take on paid gigs. Steps to building your Porty Offer your services to friends and familyUse your relevant college projects in your portfolio when you first start out.Contact a local non-profit and see if they need any helpFind out if there are any special certifications or titles held by professionals in your fieldPractice, practice, practice. Never stop honing your craft!Price yourself wisely Once you've got some experience and built up a solid portfolio, you'll be ready to start finding paid gigs. While there's no shortage of work available on the internet, a lot of it is extremely low paying. Unless you're still building a portfolio or you're just freelancing for fun, don't work for pennies. Watch the clock Take jobs you feel confident about that you can complete in a reasonable amount of time instead of taking on huge projects set yourself apart by, Delivering a unique, high quality productOffering lightning fast turnaround timeSpecializing in a particular niche, get creative with it.Value your time Decide how much you are worth per hourBe Flexible Price according to your client's needs.Do some research Get a good idea of what is reasonable and fairCommunicate with your client Your clients are your greatest resource. It is essential to form good, long standing relationships with them: Keep them in the loop with frequent updates on the progress of the work.Respond to emails and phone calls promptlySend them a draft to look over before delivering the final productBe amenable editing your work (within reason) to keep them smilingAsk for Feedback Positive feedback and great references are what's going to set you apart and even start raising your prices. Testimonials from when you can show it off. Be sure to ask if it's okay to publish your client's name and testimonial. Earning money via freelancer is a little tedious job at the beginning, but after you've done a couple of projects, you'd be able to get more projects easily. Here are some steps that you should take to start your career on freelancer.com. I have been working there from past 5 years and can share my experience.  Register your account, and make sure you have a good username (name displayed to the employer ).Complete your profile.Add a bank account to receive payments.While filling your profile, add only the skills you're perfect at, adding skills in which you are not perfect won't lead you anywhere.Add a professional profile picture, do not put your Facebook dp as your freelancer profile picture.On your info/bio, list your skills clearly, so they are visible to the employer.The most important thing is to make your portfolio, add everything you've ever made to your portfolio. Clients ask for your portfolio before hiring you.Now, some tips and tricks to get your first client. As soon as a project is posted, it will appear as a notification. Click on it, read everything clearly and then bid on it.Since this would be your first project, bid less amount. You can't expect a big bid for your first project.What clients like is, if you ask some questions related to the project. I always ask a question related to the project. This sometimes forces the employer to start a chat with you. Once he starts the chat, it's upto your way of talking and convincing him to select you ;)Getting first project is a little difficult, but work hard, make bids and ask questions. This will surely get you your first project within 7-10 days.Work your level best on the project, complete it within the deadline and make your client happy. If he is happy, he would give you good ratings and then you're a better freelancer than the newly registered ones ;) P.S :- While freelancer is great for starting, but it's slowly degrading. The freelancer staff is corrupt (search Google for freelancer scam and you'd understand what I'm saying). Good luck :)
